features.name: Bonus Combat Feat
features.desc: At 1st level, and at every even level thereafter, a fighter gains a bonus {g|Encyclopedia:Feat}feat{/g} in addition to those gained from normal advancement (meaning that the fighter gains a feat at every level). These bonus feats must be selected from those listed as Combat Feats, sometimes also called "fighter bonus feats."

features.name: Fighter Proficiencies
features.desc: A fighter is proficient with all simple and {g|Encyclopedia:Weapon_Proficiency}martial weapons{/g} and with all armor (heavy, light, and medium) and shields (including tower shields).

features.name: Bravery
features.desc: Starting at 2nd level, a fighter gains a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on Will {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}saves{/g} against fear. This bonus increases by +1 for every four levels beyond 2nd.

features.name: Armor Training
features.desc:
Starting at 3rd level, a fighter learns to be more {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Maneuvers}maneuverable{/g} while wearing armor. Whenever he is wearing armor, he reduces the armor {g|Encyclopedia:Check}check{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Penalty}penalty{/g} by 1 (to a minimum of 0) and increases the maximum {g|Encyclopedia:Dexterity}Dexterity{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} allowed by his armor by 1. Every four levels thereafter (7th, 11th, and 15th), these bonuses increase by +1 each time, to a maximum –4 reduction of the {g|Encyclopedia:Armor_Check_Penalty}armor check penalty{/g} and a +4 increase of the {g|Encyclopedia:Max_Dex_Bonus}maximum Dexterity bonus{/g} allowed.
In addition, a fighter can also move at his normal {g|Encyclopedia:Speed}speed{/g} while wearing medium armor. At 7th level, a fighter can move at his normal speed while wearing heavy armor.

features.name: Weapon Training
features.desc:
Starting at 5th level, a fighter can select one group of weapons. Whenever he {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g} with a weapon from this group, he gains a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on attack and {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g}.
Every four levels thereafter (9th, 13th, and 17th), a fighter becomes further trained in another group of weapons. He gains a +1 bonus on attack and damage {g|Encyclopedia:Dice}rolls{/g} when using a weapon from this group. In addition, the bonuses granted by previous weapon groups increase by +1 each. For example, when a fighter reaches 9th level, he receives a +1 bonus on attack and damage rolls with one weapon group and a +2 bonus on attack and damage rolls with the weapon group selected at 5th level. Bonuses granted from overlapping groups do not stack. Take the highest bonus granted for a weapon if it resides in two or more groups.
A fighter also adds this bonus to any {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Maneuvers}combat maneuver{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Check}checks{/g} made with weapons from his group. This bonus also applies to the fighter's {g|Encyclopedia:CMD}Combat Maneuver Defense{/g} when defending against disarm attempts made against weapons from this group.

features.name: Weapon Training
features.desc:
Starting at 5th level, a fighter can select one group of weapons. Whenever he {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g} with a weapon from this group, he gains a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on attack and {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g}.
Every four levels thereafter (9th, 13th, and 17th), a fighter becomes further trained in another group of weapons. He gains a +1 bonus on attack and damage {g|Encyclopedia:Dice}rolls{/g} when using a weapon from this group. In addition, the bonuses granted by previous weapon groups increase by +1 each. For example, when a fighter reaches 9th level, he receives a +1 bonus on attack and damage rolls with one weapon group and a +2 bonus on attack and damage rolls with the weapon group selected at 5th level. Bonuses granted from overlapping groups do not stack. Take the highest bonus granted for a weapon if it resides in two or more groups.
A fighter also adds this bonus to any {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Maneuvers}combat maneuver{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Check}checks{/g} made with weapons from his group. This bonus also applies to the fighter's {g|Encyclopedia:CMD}Combat Maneuver Defense{/g} when defending against disarm attempts made against weapons from this group.

features.name: Armor Mastery
features.desc: At 19th level, a fighter gains {g|Encyclopedia:Damage_Reduction}damage reduction{/g} 5/— whenever he is wearing armor or using a shield.

features.name: Weapon Mastery
features.desc: At 20th level, a fighter chooses one weapon, such as the longsword, greataxe, or longbow. Any {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g} made with that weapon automatically confirm all {g|Encyclopedia:Critical}critical{/g} threats and have their {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} multiplier increased by 1 (×2 becomes ×3, for example). In addition, he cannot be disarmed while wielding a weapon of this type.

features.name: Weapon Mastery
features.desc: At 20th level, a fighter chooses one weapon, such as the longsword, greataxe, or longbow. Any {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g} made with that weapon automatically confirm all {g|Encyclopedia:Critical}critical{/g} threats and have their {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} multiplier increased by 1 (×2 becomes ×3, for example). In addition, he cannot be disarmed while wielding a weapon of this type.

features.name: Tower Shield Evasion
features.desc: At 16th level, while using a tower shield, the tower shield specialist gains evasion, as the rogue class ability. If he makes a successful {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}Reflex saving throw{/g} against an {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} that normally deals half {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} on a successful save, he instead takes no damage.

features.name: Tower Shield Improved Evasion
features.desc: At 20th level, the shield specialist gains improved evasion, as the rogue advanced talent, while using a tower shield. This works like evasion, except that while the tower shield specialist still takes no {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} on a successful {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}Reflex saving throw{/g} against {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g}, he henceforth takes only half damage on a failed save.

features.name: Tower Shield Specialist
features.desc: At 5th level, when a tower shield specialist employs a tower shield in combat, he does not take the –2 {g|Encyclopedia:Penalty}penalty{/g} on {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack rolls{/g} because of the shield's encumbrance.

features.name: Tower Shield Defense
features.desc: At 9th level, while using a tower shield, a tower shield specialist gains his shield {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} against {g|Encyclopedia:TouchAttack}touch attacks{/g}.

features.name: Total Cover
features.desc: At 13th level, while using a tower shield, a tower shield specialist cannot be {g|Encyclopedia:Flanking}flanked{/g}.

features.name: Weapon Proficiency (Dueling Sword)
features.desc: You become proficient with dueling swords and can use them as a weapon.

features.name: Draconic Bloodline
features.desc: Each dragonheir scion can draw her lineage back to the influence of a great draconic progenitor. At 1st level, a dragonheir scion must select one of the chromatic or metallic dragon types. Once chosen, this cannot be changed. A number of dragonheir scion's abilities deal {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} and grant resistances based on her dragon type, as noted below. If a dragonheir scion takes a level in another class that grants a bloodline, the bloodlines must be of the same type, even if that means that the bloodline of one of the classes must change.

features.name: Arcane Strike
features.desc: Spending a {g|Encyclopedia:Swift_Action}swift action{/g} each {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Round}round{/g}, you can imbue your weapons with a fraction of your power. For 1 round, your weapons deal +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} and are treated as magic for the purpose of overcoming {g|Encyclopedia:Damage_Reduction}damage reduction{/g}. For every five {g|Encyclopedia:Caster_Level}caster levels{/g} you possess, this {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} increases by +1, to a maximum of +5 at 20th level.

features.name: Fearful Might
features.desc: At 2nd level, a dragonheir scion gains a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on {g|Encyclopedia:Persuasion}Persuasion{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Skills}skill checks{/g} made to intimidate. This bonus increases to +2 at 6th level and by an additional 1 every 4 fighter levels thereafter to a maximum of +5 at 18th level.

features.name: Draconic Presence
features.desc: At 6th level, the dragonheir scion receives Dazzling Display as a bonus {g|Encyclopedia:Feat}feat{/g}. She does not need a weapon in hand to use this ability, and can use it as a {g|Encyclopedia:Standard_Actions}standard action{/g}.

features.name: Defensive Parry
features.desc: At 3rd level, when a swordlord makes a full {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} with a dueling sword, he gains a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} to {g|Encyclopedia:Armor_Class}AC{/g} against {g|Encyclopedia:MeleeAttack}melee attacks{/g} until the beginning of his next turn. This bonus increases by +1 every four levels after 3rd.

features.name: Disarming Strike
features.desc: At 6th level, when a swordlord successfully disarms an opponent using a dueling sword, the swordlord also deals normal {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} to the target, but without the normal {g|Encyclopedia:Strength}Strength{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} to damage.

features.name: Steel Net
features.desc: At 8th level, a swordlord can throw up a blazing wall of steel to defend himself. When fighting defensively with a dueling sword, the swordlord's {g|Encyclopedia:Penalty}penalties{/g} on all {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g} in a {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Round}round{/g} are reduced by 2, and the dodge {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} to {g|Encyclopedia:Armor_Class}AC{/g} is increased by 2 for the same round.

features.name: Counterattack
features.desc: At 10th level, a swordlord can make an {g|Encyclopedia:Attack_Of_Opportunity}attack of opportunity{/g} as an immediate {g|Encyclopedia:CA_Types}action{/g} against an opponent who hits the swordlord with a {g|Encyclopedia:MeleeAttack}melee attack{/g}, so long as the {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacking{/g} creature is within the swordlord's {g|Encyclopedia:Reach}reach{/g}.

features.name: Burst Barrier
features.desc: At 2nd level, a tower shield specialist can use his shield to screen himself from burst {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spells{/g} and effects, gaining a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on Reflex {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}saves{/g} against them while employing a tower shield. This bonus increases by +1 for every four levels after 2nd (to a maximum of +5 at 18th level).

features.name: Tower Shield Training
features.desc: At 3rd level, a tower shield specialist gains armor training as normal, but while he employs a tower shield, the armor {g|Encyclopedia:Penalty}penalty{/g} is reduced by 3 and the maximum {g|Encyclopedia:Dexterity}Dexterity{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} allowed by his tower shield increases by 2. The benefit increases every four levels thereafter as per standard armor training; if the tower shield specialist is not employing a tower shield, the benefits to armor training revert to the normal bonuses.

features.name: Strong Grip
features.desc: At 2nd level, a {g|Encyclopedia:Light_Weapon}two-handed{/g} fighter gains a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} to {g|Encyclopedia:CMB}CMB{/g} and {g|Encyclopedia:CMD}CMD{/g} on sunder attempts and on disarm attempts. These bonuses increase by +1 for every four levels beyond 2nd.

features.name: Two-Handed Weapon Training
features.desc: Whenever {g|Encyclopedia:Light_Weapon}two-handed{/g} fighter {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attacks{/g} with a weapon from this group, he gains a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on attack and {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g}.

features.name: Overhand Chop
features.desc: At 3rd level, when a {g|Encyclopedia:Light_Weapon}two-handed{/g} fighter makes a single {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} (with the attack {g|Encyclopedia:CA_Types}action{/g} or a charge) with a two-handed weapon, he adds double his {g|Encyclopedia:Strength}Strength{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g}.

features.name: Backswing
features.desc: At 7th level, when a {g|Encyclopedia:Light_Weapon}two-handed{/g} fighter makes a full {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} with a two-handed weapon, he adds double his {g|Encyclopedia:Strength}Strength{/g} {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage rolls{/g} for all attacks after the first.

features.name: Piledriver
features.desc: At 11th level, as a {g|Encyclopedia:Standard_Actions}standard action{/g}, a {g|Encyclopedia:Light_Weapon}two-handed{/g} fighter can make a single {g|Encyclopedia:MeleeAttack}melee attack{/g} with a two-handed weapon. If the {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} hits, he may make a bull rush or trip {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Maneuvers}combat maneuver{/g} against the target of his attack as a {g|Encyclopedia:Free_Action}free action{/g} that does not provoke an {g|Encyclopedia:Attack_Of_Opportunity}attack of opportunity{/g}.

features.name: Greater Power Attack
features.desc: At 15th level, when using Power {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}Attack{/g} with a {g|Encyclopedia:Light_Weapon}two-handed{/g} melee weapon, the bonus {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} from Power Attack is doubled (+100%) instead of increased by half (+50%).

features.name: Devastating Blow
features.desc: At 19th level, as a {g|Encyclopedia:Standard_Actions}standard action{/g}, a {g|Encyclopedia:Light_Weapon}two-handed{/g} fighter may make a single {g|Encyclopedia:MeleeAttack}melee attack{/g} with a two-handed weapon at a –5 {g|Encyclopedia:Penalty}penalty{/g}. If the {g|Encyclopedia:Attack}attack{/g} hits, it is treated as a {g|Encyclopedia:Critical}critical{/g} threat. Special weapon abilities that activate only on a critical hit do not activate if this critical hit is confirmed.

features.name: Order
features.desc: A character must choose one Hellknight order to join at 1st level. The choice of order determines what disciplines the character gains later access to.

features.name: Studious Squire
features.desc:
An armiger gains 1 additional {g|Encyclopedia:Skills}skill{/g} rank at each level.
In addition, the armiger treats {g|Encyclopedia:Knowledge_World}Knowledge (world){/g} as class skill.
This alters the fighter's class skills and skill points per level, and replaces the fighter's bonus {g|Encyclopedia:Feat}feats{/g} gained at 1st and 10th levels.

features.name: Ardent
features.desc:
Armigers are difficult to sway from their beliefs. At 2nd level, an armiger gains a +1 {g|Encyclopedia:Bonus}bonus{/g} on Will {g|Encyclopedia:Saving_Throw}saves{/g} against charm and compulsion effects. This bonus increases by 1 for every 4 fighter levels beyond 2nd.
Additionally, the first time per day armiger fails a saving throw against a charm or compulsion effect, he {g|Encyclopedia:Dice}rerolls{/g} the saving throw with the same {g|Encyclopedia:DC}DC{/g}.
This replaces bravery.

features.name: Mutagen
features.desc: At 3rd level, a mutation warrior discovers how to create a mutagen that he can imbibe in order to heighten his physical prowess at the cost of his personality. This ability functions as the alchemist's mutagen ability, using his fighter level as his alchemist level.

features.name: Mutagen Discovery
features.desc: At 7th level and every 4 levels thereafter, the mutation warrior can choose one of the following alchemist discoveries to augment his abilities: feral mutagen, grand mutagen, greater mutagen, nauseating flesh, preserve organs, spontaneous {g|Encyclopedia:Healing}healing{/g}, feral wings. The mutation warrior uses his fighter level as his effective alchemist level for the purpose of these discoveries.

name: Fighter
desc: Fighters excel at combat—defeating their enemies, controlling the flow of battle, and surviving such sorties themselves. While their specific weapons and methods grant them a wide variety of tactics, few can match fighters for sheer battle prowess.

archetypes.name: Dragonheir Scion
archetypes.desc: Dragonheir scions are the martially inclined humanoid descendants of those influenced by draconic power. Unlike their sorcerous brethren, dragonheir scions manifest their heritage in ways more suited to {g|Encyclopedia:Strength}strength{/g} of arms and {g|Encyclopedia:Skills}skill{/g} with steel than arcane energies. Those who follow this path are often the children of mighty dragon-blooded sorcerers and others who drew energy from their dragon blood, though they themselves might not exhibit {g|Encyclopedia:Spell}spellcasting{/g} ability.

archetypes.name: Aldori Defender
archetypes.desc: The Aldori Swordlords of Brevoy are among the deadliest and most feared fighters of the Inner Sea. They have spent long years mastering the Aldori dueling sword, pitting themselves against other dueling swords and all manner of weaponry besides. Their {g|Encyclopedia:Speed}speed{/g} and reflexes weave a net of impenetrable steel around them, from which they strike and harry their unfortunate opponents. The most common form of Aldori dueling (and arguably the easiest of the techniques to master) focuses on avoiding {g|Encyclopedia:Damage}damage{/g} and disarming foes; these swordlords prefer to wear light or no armor, trusting their {g|Encyclopedia:Skills}skill{/g} for protection.

archetypes.name: Tower Shield Specialist
archetypes.desc: Many fighters believe the tower shield is a tool suitable only for troops on the battlefield, claiming it is too large and bulky to use in skirmishes or within dungeon corridors. Tower shield specialists defy those notions, using their massive shields with startling {g|Encyclopedia:Skills}skill{/g} and incredible effect. They use these seemingly clumsy shields to perform deft {g|Encyclopedia:Combat_Maneuvers}maneuvers{/g} that confound their enemies.

archetypes.name: Two-Handed Fighter
archetypes.desc: Some fighters focus their efforts on finding the biggest, heaviest, most imposing weapon they can find and training to manage and harness the weight of their massive weapons for maximum impact. These fighting school benefits only apply when using {g|Encyclopedia:Light_Weapon}two-handed{/g} weapons.

archetypes.name: Armiger
archetypes.desc:
Until would-be Hellknights take the trial referred to simply as the Test — in which they enter single combat with a conjured devil and either emerge victorious or die — they are known as armigers. While this is a blanket term for all Hellknights-in-training (including those training to become signifers), it also applies specifically to fighters who focus their training to become Hellknights. Despite their lack of recognized rank, armigers are skilled and deadly warriors.
Most armigers live and train at their order's citadel, working toward the day when they become full-fledged Hellknights. These armigers follow a brutally strict routine; they spend hours honing their combat skills against other trainees, obsessively studying in the citadel's libraries, or memorizing passages of the Hellknight philosophy known as the Measure and the Chain. At regular intervals, squads of armigers emerge from their citadels to patrol nearby cities or frontier lands, working to enforce Hellknight law and their order's edicts.

archetypes.name: Mutation Warrior
archetypes.desc: While most fighters rely on physical fitness and rigorous training to achieve martial superiority, a few prefer to create and imbibe dangerous concoctions that transform them into fearsome creatures.
